column2: 'UFO Vanishes in FranceThis case was originally brought to light by renown researcher Jacques Vallee
column3: and it is a strange one indeed. Occurring at Nouatre
column6: it is a case unlike any other
column7: and yet all of the witnesses to the event are considered trustworthy
column8: and their strange sighting has never been debunked. American ufology students have treated this case with little credibility
column9: but serious investigators have embraced it as genuine. It began at a construction site at 4:30 P.M. on September 30
column11: who was foreman of an eight-man construction crew
column12: was unexpectedly drawn away from his crew
column13: feeling a sense of 'peculiar drowsiness.' He was walking
column14: but did not know why or to where. A short distance from his construction site
column15: Gatay was amazed to encounter a man standing on a slope
column16: some 30 feet from him. The 'man' was wearing an opaque glass helmet with a large visor. He was wearing gray coveralls
column17: and short boots. He also held an object in his hand
column18: which Gatay described as a weapon of some kind
column19: like a rod. There was a kind of electronic instrument display on his chest. This strange looking man was standing in front of a dome-shaped object
column20: which hovered about 3 feet above the ground.The craft had a cupola with blade-like devices above it. Gatay
column21: enthralled with the sight of the man and his craft
column22: was frozen in his tracks. Gatay stated: 'Suddenly
column24: and I couldn\'t explain how he did it
column25: since he did not disappear from my field of vision by walking away
column26: but vanished like an image one erases. Then I heard a strong whistling sound which drowned the noise of our excavators. Soon the object rose by successive jerks
column28: and then it too was erased in a sort of blue haze
column29: as if by a miracle.'Gatay had tried to run after first seeing the being and object
column30: but was 'paralyzed' during the sighting. Strangely
column31: his seven co-workers were also in a sort of a daze during the incident. All eight of the men were 'non-believers' before their strange incident. As soon as Gatay was released from his strange encounter
column32: he ran back to the other workers
column34: 'Have you seen something?' One of the men
column37: 'Yes--A flying saucer!' Another of the men
column39: 'There was a man dressed like a diver in front of it.' The other workers all added their confirmation to the strange event. Gatay was a well-known and respected man who had fought in the war with the French Resistance
column40: and was wounded in Luxembourg. After the sighting
column41: he began to suffer from insomnia
column43: and a loss of appetite. These symptoms lasted about a week. Even after this strange sighting
column44: the men collectively believed that they had been witnesses to some type of experimental craft
column45: probably from France itself. This explanation was not feasible given the details of the hovering of the craft
column46: and the actual vanishing of the craft in front of the men. What was this other-wordly craft seen by these men? And the being
column48: or a remotely controlled robot of some type? To this day
column49: no reasonable explanation has been given to answer these questions
column50: and this case is still listed as unexplained.B J Booth sources:Article:  Jacques Vallée

column87: 'Did President Eisenhower Meet with Aliens in 1954?One of the first conclusions an impartial observer must make about the subject of UFOs is that rumors and circumstance play far too great a role in what ought to be a more exacting quest for knowledge. It is just such an observation which once led Dr. Carl Sagan to comment dryly that UFOs 'are more a matter for religion and superstition than they are for science.' While this dismissal is perhaps unscientific in its own right
column88: the point is well taken. Attend any gathering of 'UFO people' you want
column89: and simply listen. Rumors abound. Perhaps worse
column91: is that some of these rumors manage to circulate for years (even decades) without anyone making a reasonable effort to get to the bottom of them. One of the most persistent of these is a story that President Eisenhower visited Edwards Air Force Base in early 1954
column92: and either viewed the bodies of dead aliens and the wreckage of their craft
column93: or met with live aliens on some sort of diplomatic mission to earth. The story takes many forms
column94: with the common thread being that Ike mysteriously disappeared one evening while on a vacation to Palm Springs
column95: and that he was spirited to Edwards to view (or meet) aliens. It is said that he returned by dawn and shortly thereafter ordered absolute secrecy about anything having to do with UFOs. No doubt one of the reasons that this particular rumor has continued to circulate for such a long time is that there are a number of verifiable facts associated with it--some of them rather curious. For example
column96: President Eisenhower did indeed make a trip to Palm Springs between February 17th and 24th
column98: and on the evening of Saturday
column100: he did disappear! When members of the press learned that the president was not where he should be
column101: rumors ran rampant that he had either died or was seriously ill. The story even managed to get onto a press wire before being killed moments later. To quell the fuss
column102: White House Press Secretary James Haggerty called an urgent late evening press conference to announce 'solemnly' that the president had been enjoying fried chicken earlier that evening
column103: had knocked a cap off a tooth
column104: and had been taken to a local dentist for treatment. When Ike turned up as scheduled the next morning for an early church service
column105: the matter seemed ended. Although the Palm Springs trip was billed as a 'vacation for the president'
column106: the trip appears to have come up rather suddenly. In addition
column107: it is a matter of record that Ike had returned from a quail shooting vacation in Georgia less than a week before leaving for Palm Springs. While the incidence of a local dentist being called upon to treat a president of the United States is unusual enough that it should constitute a rather memorable event for those involved
column111: was curiously unable to recall any specifics relating to her husband\'s alleged involvement in the affair--not even the time of day it had occurred. Yet her memory appeared flawless when asked to relate details of her and her husband\'s attendance (by presidential invitation) at a steak fry the following evening
column112: where her husband was introduced as 'the dentist who had treated the president'. This would appear to suggest a cover story
column113: the details of which would have easily been repeated at the time
column114: but quite naturally forgotten 25 years later. Research at the Eisenhower Library has uncovered two other facts inconsistent with the dentist story. The first is that while the library maintains an extensive index of records relating to the president\'s health
column115: there is no record of any dental work having been performed at all during February
column116: 1954. A file on 'Dentists' contains nothing concerning any such incident either. Secondly
column117: there is a large file containing copies of all sorts of acknowledgments which were sent by the White House to people who had something to do with the Palm Springs trip. There are letters
column121: people who had offered to play golf
column122: etc. There is even a thank you letter to the minister who presided over the Sunday service Ike attended. Yet there is no record of any acknowledgment having been sent to 'the dentist who treated the president.' If the matter were as routine as Haggerty attempts to make it appear
column123: then the absence of these records seems strangely inconsistent. The rumor of the president\'s alleged visit to Edwards is not a new one. UFO contactee fringe writers began making unsupported claims about it less than two months after Ike\'s trip. So did a bizarre fellow from the Hollywood hills named Gerald Light
column126: 1954 letter to the head of a Southern California metaphysical organization
column127: actually claimed to have been at Edwards where he saw Ike
column128: the saucers and the aliens. Light\'s letter has been controversial for years and copies of it have turned up in all sorts of places
column129: including the National Enquirer. Investigation into Mr. Light\'s background
column131: turned up the fact that he was an elderly mystic who believed that psychic 'out-of-body-experiences' were a logical extension of the reality of life and should be treated as such. In the final analysis
column132: Light\'s alleged visit to Edwards was just such an experience. And so the story ends. Clearly something unusual occurred involving the president on the evening of February 20
column133: 1954. Whether it was a trip to the dentist
column134: a trip to see flying saucers
column135: or something altogether different and unrelated
column136: no one can say. It\'s the stuff rumors are made of.  Source & References:William H. MooreGazette
